destination.label: Bordeaux
destination.title: Bordeaux, region of sand and water, land of wine and pine

content.intro:
On the heels of its long history, heritage like no other and newfound dynamism, Bordeaux is the successful blend of Parisian-style bourgeois chic and southern coolness.

'The Pearl of Aquitaine', long known as 'The Sleeping Beauty' has woken up. Named a UNESCO World Heritage site in 2007 and "Best European Destination" in 2015, the city has shown for some years now that it is unquestionably a showcase for the art of French living. Wandering the cobbled streets will bring you to shopping central on rue Sainte-Catherine, the longest pedestrian street in Europe, stretching over a kilometre; stroll along the walled banks of the Garonne, through the many squares dotted with sidewalk cafés, bars, and restaurants, and stop to taste oysters, a landaise salad, a duck breast accompanied by a fine wine, and of course the traditional cannelé (caramelised custard pastry), the star of Bordeaux delicacies.
It is a 'land of contrasts' between vineyards and forest, freshwater and saltwater, blue-grey sky and the silty ochre waves of the river; no longer exactly a river, nor yet the ocean, the estuary surprises and has a mysterious side. Discover this paradoxical universe the port surrounded by land, the countryside in the middle of the sea.
Meandering through the great vineyard regions offers incomparable vistas, along with an astounding list of world-renowned wines from the Medoc to Saint-Émilion. Pomerol, Pauillac, Saint-Estèphe, Margaux and all the great growths are invitations to travel and visiting vineyards is undoubtedly the best way to better understand the subtleties of what you find in your glass. Bordeaux wines have offered fame and prosperity to the 'Port of the Moon' and are exported worldwide, ensuring an exceptional image of the art of French living. 'Be you drunken', wrote Baudelaire - but if one really knows how to live well, be so in moderation, of course.
Further west, the Atlantic surf rolls in with a promising roar, offering a few ocean nirvanas for surfers and seekers of good spots. In alliance with the ocean winds, the sea raises the mountains of sand at the foot of the cultivated Landes pine forest, and then gives birth to a desert, the Dune de Pilat, which breaks all records in terms of size and height. Once past the great fields of sand, you will arrive at Arcachon Bay, an amazing area of inland sea, beaches, oyster parks, and eco-tourism sites with a variety of entries protected by channels. Once there, let yourself be carried away by the rejuvenating benefits of seaside life.

content.title: MÉCA, emblem of Bordeaux's contemporary culture

introduction.small: Highpoint of the neighbourhood transformation of Saint-Jean Belcier, MÉCA is a hybrid between creative residence and exhibition area, overlooking the Garonne river with its defying architecture.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: MÉCA, emblem of Bordeaux's contemporary culture

paragraphs.text:
Walking along the Garonne river on the Paludate docks, it is impossible to miss the huge geometrical structure that blends harmoniously in the landscape. This architectural endeavour, an arch made of Bordeaux's white stone, with scale-looking windows on inclined walls, shelters the Maison de l'Économie Créative et Culturelle en Nouvelle-Aquitaine (the "region's new House of creative and cultural economy"), usually called "MÉCA". Built upon former slaughterhouses near the Saint-Jean station, it is not only a hybrid location with artist residences and a creative incubator, as MÉCA offers various exhibitions areas dedicated to contemporary art initiated by the FRAC (regional collection of contemporary art) of Nouvelle-Aquitaine as well. Regional cultural agencies, creative forces and citizens coexist in this hub of local creation and art. The various works take most of the space, up to the 800-sqm rooftop, with a 180° view over Bordeaux. The artist residences offer solid ground to performing companies looking to test out their creations with an audience and prepare for tours. They sometimes perform in MÉCA's auditorium, which is free of charge for all visitors inside the building at the moment of the performance.

content.title: Le Prince Noir, the star that shines on Bordeaux

introduction.small: On a hill in Lormont, facing the Bacalan, Vivien Durand blends southwestern influences with modern creativity in his restaurant, Le Prince Noir.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Prince Noir, the star that shines on Bordeaux

paragraphs.text:
Far from the uptight and solemn nature of starred restaurants that used to be, Le Prince Noir stands out with its friendly cuisine that puts the pleasures of tasting food back at the centre of it all. The building itself, a cube of glass and concrete perched high up in Lormont in a green setting that gives onto the Aquitaine bridge, is surrounded by the stables of Lormont castle. Chef Vivien Durant took over from Jean-Marie Amat, local figure of gastronomy who passed away in 2018. Now crowned with a Michelin star, the chef reveals local inspirations in sharp contrast with the very contemporary aspect of his creations: flavours are impactful, products (mostly local) are highlighted according to the seasons. Thus, you may come across some of the following during the Prince Noir 4 or 6-course menu: milk-fed lamb and crumble-like couscous polenta, matured Herriko chuck steak, foie gras braised over some "kasha" (peeled and grilled buckwheat) or the kokotxa - an herb soup in pilpil - which is definitely a Basque speciality. Note that there is an interesting lunch menu which makes this starred cuisine affordable to more gourmets.

Le Prince Noir
1 rue du Prince Noir
33310 Lormont

+33 (0)5 56 06 12 52

https://www.leprincenoir-restaurant.fr/

Menu: from 95 EUR (“Edouard de Woodstock” set menu)

content.title: The covered market of yesteryear is back in Bacalan

introduction.small: On the Pontac promenade, a stone's throw from the Chaban-Delmas bridge, the Halles de Bacalan gather a selection of Southwest producers as a rallying symbol of local gastronomy.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: The covered market of yesteryear is back in Bacalan

paragraphs.text:
Facing the Garonne river, near the Cité du Vin and the Grain silo, the laminated wood roof of the Bacalan covered market catches the eye. Before you even step in, the large picture windows will give you an enticing glimpse of what awaits. The food market itself spreads over 1,000 sqm, with about twenty stalls offers their products daily, except on Monday. Among them, many merchants and producers favour local distribution channels, as 85% of what you find in Bacalan is actually produced in the southwest of France. Butcher and pork butcher shops, fishmongers, poultry and oyster farmers, foie gras specialists, cheese, wine and truffle producers, greengrocers and bakers abound, including a vegetarian deli! Those high-end merchants will give you a pretty exhaustive idea of local gastronomy. All year long, various events and animations take place: cooking lessons, plays, concerts… Paying further tribute to its location, the Bacalan market also welcome a brewery, the Familia, which used to be an emblematic establishment - at once bar, restaurant and movie theatre - from the 1930s to the 1970s.

Les Halles de Bacalan by Biltoki

33300 Bordeaux

content.title: Hangar Darwin, alternative hangout and a must in Bordeaux

introduction.small: Outside the scope of usual tourist attractions, Hangar Darwin is the spearhead of Bordeaux's urban culture, with photo exhibitions, street art and a skatepark.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hangar Darwin, alternative hangout and a must in Bordeaux

paragraphs.text:
Usually, locals ride their bike, rollerblades, skateboard or simply walk on the right bank in the Bastide neighbourhood when they go to Hangar Darwin. There, recycling is a second nature, as all unused materials and products will find a new lease life in a modern and eco-friendly way. Lively, creative and alternative, the Hangar (French for "warehouse") is a hybrid location where people come for lunch, wander about, enjoy street art exhibitions, and of course practice all kinds of board sports.

In this former army storage spreading over 2,700 sqm, military equipment made way for an indoor skatepark built using recycled materials. Whatever your age, put your helmet on and prove yourself in the wooden "bowl", on the ramp or on the various small modules installed here and there. Private and collective skating lessons are available, regardless of age or level, courtesy of the Brigade (the "crew"), who manage the place.

Hangar Darwin is not exclusively dedicated to wheels: with street art, photo exhibitions, and hip-hop concerts, the site pays tribute to all urban cultures.

Hangar Darwin

33100 Bordeaux

+33 (0)9 53 01 86 22

content.title: La Halle Boca, iconic food court of Bordeaux's new city centre

introduction.small: In Bordeaux's Saint-Jean Belcier centre, La Halle Boca draws inspiration from American food courts and unveils about fifteen gastronomic options.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Halle Boca, iconic food court of Bordeaux's new city centre

paragraphs.text:
The glass building reflecting the Garonne River is hard to miss. Amidst the Euratlantique business district, La Halle Boca embodies the recent change that took over Bordeaux's hypercentre. Built where the old city slaughterhouse and Debat-Pensan covered market stood since 1938, this hybrid location is positioned halfway between office space, hotel and restaurant court. The food section is spread over almost 7,000 sqm and welcomes 16 gastronomical stands and a central bar. There is Vapiano and its Italian-influenced cuisine, for example, or the Garde-Manger, an outpost of Bordeaux restaurant La Petite Garonne that also functions as a deli. Unless you would rather try the La Boca Food Court, of course: a large 1,300 sqm space opened for all-day dining, seven days a week, serving healthy street food. Small eaters and sophisticated food lovers will all find what they are looking for.

Halle Boca

www.halleboca.com

content.title: La Grande Poste, cultural centre par excellence

introduction.small: Head to the former main post office of Bordeaux where you can have something to eat… and also something to see!

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Grande Poste, cultural centre par excellence

paragraphs.text:
Enter this Art Deco building redone by architects Corinne Page and Jean-Louis Valadié. Imagined by Marilyne Minault, it aims to be eclectic and contains several cultural centres. You can take the opportunity to taste Chef Christophe Cappi's dishes and his bistronomic cuisine and enjoy a delicious roasted stone bass loin with sweet potato mash, ginger and coriander, or the folded duck breast with roasted seasonal fruits and spices. For dessert, do not miss the honey roasted peach with vanilla, a real delight.

Once your meal is over, there are several spaces available to visit. You can enjoy a drink in the bar on the ground floor and attend one of the various performances programmed throughout the year. Every month, find pop-up shops upstairs where designers and craftsmen present their creations. You will discover their universe and may leave with some of their works!

content.title: Experience a unique moment at the Wave Surf Café

introduction.small: A board in one hand, a drink in the other and you will be off to surf an (artificial) wave.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Experience a unique moment at the Wave Surf Café

paragraphs.text:
Located in the Galerie Tatry, in the Chartrons district, the Wave Surf Café offers, besides what you can find in a traditional café, a water trail for 25 or 55-minute sessions of pure pleasure. Novices, amateurs or those more experienced in surfing or bodyboarding, you will be curious to experiment, alone or with friends, this original sport practice on an artificial wave. Regulars will tell you that it is similar to other board sports, such as skimboard for fluidity, skateboarding for tricks and snowboarding for turns.

You can also just watch or take a well-deserved break. All kinds of drinks including tea, coffee, hot chocolate, smoothies, wine and beer are available, as well as little snacks like real American hot dogs and croque monsieur. In France, the bars that offer this concept are still not very well known - the Wave Surf Café is the only one to offer indoor waves and be open all year round.

introduction.small: A unique location, dedicated to wine culture.

paragraphs.text:
The Cité du Vin is a unique leisure and culture location where the soul of wine can express itself, offering an immersive and sensorial experience in a suggestive architecture. It gives a different viewpoint on wines across the world, through time, culture and civilization.
An immersive circuit of more than 3,000 sqm takes through time and space and discover wine in all its diversity. With temporary exhibitions, wine tastings, events and shows in the auditorium, a reading lounge, but also restaurants, shops, an oenotouristic platform, gardens and a pontoon, the Cité du Vin offers a brand new meeting place with culture on the forefront, now a must-see in Bordeaux.

content.title: Pont de Pierre and Pont Jacques Chaban-Delmas

introduction.small: Of the seven bridges spanning the Garonne, a river that locals once thought indomitable, these two are among the city's most iconic structures.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Pont de Pierre and Pont Jacques Chaban-Delmas

paragraphs.text:
The Pont de Pierre, also called the "Pont Napoléon" after the French Emperor who ordered it built, was the first road bridge to allow the Bordelais to cross the Garonne, thereby connecting the city centre with the Bastide districts on the right bank. Work began in December 1812, and the bridge was inaugurated ten years later on 1 May 1822. Contrary to popular belief, although this bridge does have 17 arches, it was not in homage to the 17 letters in Napoleon Bonaparte's name. However, it is a listed historical monument, and is also hollow: once a year during the European Heritage Days, visitors are given the chance to go inside.

A few kilometres further north, the Pont Jacques Chaban-Delmas - the largest vertical lift bridge in Europe - was opened on 18 March 2013 after three years of work. It connects the Quai de Bacalan with the Quai de Brazza to the north of La Bastide, which it why it was originally known as the 'Pont Bacalan-Bastide'. However, a few weeks after the bridge was opened, local authorities decided to rename.it the ‘Pont Jacques Chaban-Delmas' after a former mayor who served the city of Bordeaux for almost half a century.

Pont de Pierre and Pont Chaban-Delmas

https://www.bordeaux-tourism.co.uk/cultural-heritage/pont-pierre.html

content.title: Seeko'o Hotel, designer iceberg and Eskimo comfort

introduction.small: Spend magical moments in a modern area of ​​the historical district of the Chartrons.

The hotel is ideally situated opposite the promenade from the River Garonne and near the trendy restaurants of the city, arising among the 18th-century façades and stonewalls as a futuristic architectural challenge. Conceived by the local architecture agency King Kong, the hotel mirrors the city's embrace for modernity, with refined lines and very graphic style. Very well situated, it will be an ideal starting point to wander off and discover Bordeaux.

Its 44 rooms are designed in open loft spaces (from 27 to 55 sqm), each with a king size bed and with bathrooms offering a luxurious tub for two.

Enjoy the 'Happy Hour' at the Seeko'o Bar on the first floor and sample classic cocktails (in moderation) or a glass of wine if you prefer, alongside a selection of Iberian dishes.

content.title: Three centuries of history on the Place de la Bourse

introduction.small: The former Place Royale opening onto the Garonne, the Place de la Bourse was originally dedicated to King Louis XV.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Three centuries of history on the Place de la Bourse

paragraphs.text:
The architect of the Place de la Bourse, Ange-Jacques Gabriel, was inspired by the design of the Place Vendôme in Paris. The two historic buildings framing the square are also a wonderful sight: one is the Palais de la Bourse (now home to the city's Chamber of Commerce and Industry), and the other is the National Museum of Customs. Pediments adorned with masks and the ironwork of the buildings illustrate the history of the city. At the centre of the square stands an iconic, majestic statue that reflects the ruler or era: the original statue of King Louis XV on horseback was replaced soon after the French Revolution by a “tree of liberty”, which in turn was changed in 1869 to the bronze and marble Three Graces Fountain that remains today.

Since July 2006, the largest water mirror in the world (3,450 sqm), designed by landscape architect Michel Corajoud has occupied the final side of the Place de la Bourse. Situated between the Quay de la Douane and the Quay Louis XVIII, it reflects the facades of the monuments with magical light effects. The square has become a favourite spot for locals, especially on hot summer days when children splash about on the thin surface of water to cool off.

Place de la Bourse and Miroir d'Eau

content.title: Public Garden: architect Ange-Jacques Gabriel looks after this Garden of Eden

introduction.small: Created in 1746 in a style inspired by Versailles landscape artist Le Nôtre, this was the first garden in France designed from its inception to be open to the public.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Public Garden: architect Ange-Jacques Gabriel looks after this Garden of Eden

paragraphs.text:
Created at the request of the Marquis de Tourney Louis-Urbain Aubert, transformed into a landscaped garden by Ange-Jacques Gabriel, then reconfigured in 1858 under the leadership of the Bordelais landscape architect Louis-Bernard Fischer who gave it the English style it has today, this 'Outstanding Garden of France' houses an arboretum, a library, and a museum of natural history. It offers an ideal spot to study or read amidst magnolias or under willows caressing the expansive green lawn areas, or perhaps while sitting near the large pond - which was excavated in 1856 in the form of a serpentine river - and its three wrought-iron bridges. Stop near the Place du Champ-de-Mars between the Rue Ducaus and Place Longchamp, where you will be able to see the compound's wrought-iron gate in all its glory: some of its sections are actually still original, and are listed historic monuments.

Children can freely run about the entire garden, play ball, ride on swings in the playground, or even have a go on the old merry-go-round, while parents enjoy a moment of respite and a chat on a park bench. However, the shouts of young children as you pass the puppet theatre will undoubtedly draw you to the over-excited crowd of toddlers as they plead, "Watch out Guignol, look behind you!" (In French, of course).

Jardin Public
Cours de Verdun
33000 Bordeaux

https://www.bordeaux.fr/ville/jardin-public

content.title: From the Dune du Pilat to the Cap-Ferret

introduction.small: From beautiful antique villas to small oyster ports, traditional fishing boats to pleasure boats, sandy beaches to authentic oyster tasting huts, the Arcachon Bay has something for everyone.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: From the Dune du Pilat to the Cap-Ferret

paragraphs.text:
Arcachon Bay is a fragile, engaging natural environment in perpetual motion, subject to the wrath of the ocean and human whims. Located 70km from Bordeaux, this formidable nature reservoir crisscrossed with pathways is actually a mesotidal lagoon (meaning it has a tidal range of one to six metres), and is surrounded by a dozen picturesque villages and towns.

Before starting your tour, begin by admiring the scenery from the Dune du Pilat, from which the view is spectacular: on one side, there is the green of 2,400 hectares of pine forests, and on the other, bluish monochrome ocean, the golden slopes of the Banc d'Arguin, and the silhouette of Cap Ferret and its lighthouse. Climb up the highest dune in Europe along the ridge before slowly making your way back down to the beachfront. Then take a boat ride from Arcachon and the coastal villages around the Île aux Oiseaux (Bird Island), where you will find a number of wooden huts on stilts that are typical of the region. Called "cabanes tchanquées", they are today, along with the Dune du Pilat, the emblem of the Bay.

content.title: Place du Palais and Porte Cailhau, Bordeaux's most beautiful entry

introduction.small: In the Middle Ages, the Palais Ombrière served as the residence of the dukes of Aquitaine. After it was destroyed in 1800, the spot was renamed the Place du Palais.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Place du Palais and Porte Cailhau, Bordeaux's most beautiful entry

paragraphs.text:
It is a small quiet spot, hidden in the shade of the 35-metre-high Porte Cailhau; beautiful and slender as a young bride despite its great age, the silhouette of the ancient gateway to the city of Bordeaux has hardly changed since its construction between 1493 and 1496.

The Porte Cailhau, which used to be a fortress and an arch of triumph, commemorates the victory of Fornovo in Italy by King Charles VIII of France, whose image adorns a niche on the riverside. Its lattice windows, sculptures and conic roofing make it an uncommon piece of architecture in Bordeaux.

After several changes and renovations, including the decision to discontinue using the Place du Palais as a bus terminal, most of the area was pedestrianised in 2009. From the square, look through the Porte Cailhau archway to see the oldest bridge in Bordeaux in the distance: the Pont de Pierre.

Place du Palais and Porte Cailhau
33000 Bordeaux

https://www.bordeaux-tourism.co.uk/cultural-heritage/porte-cailhau.html

content.title: La Grosse Cloche: a resounding remnant of the Middle Ages

introduction.small: Emblematic figure of its neighbourhood, the Grosse Cloche leans against the Saint-Éloi Church, where magistrates took oaths. It is one of the few monuments from the Middle Ages that remains.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Grosse Cloche: a resounding remnant of the Middle Ages

paragraphs.text:
The evocation of the Grosse Cloche ("Great Bell" in English) in Bordeaux necessarily refers to the whole monument of which it was part, but which is now destroyed. Built in the 15th century on the remains of the ancient Porte Saint-Éloi, the belfry comprises two 41-metre towers connected by a central building. As for the bell, that was cast in 1775 by the founder Turmel. It weighs 7,800 kilograms and measures two metres tall, which explains its name.

In times gone by, the bell was used to announce important events such as the grape harvest or a fire. Because of this, the King was always quick to remove it - and all the clocks - when he wanted the city punished. Recently restored, the Grosse Cloche is noted for its gilded copper weathervane representing the English lion. This lion is often also said to be the symbol of Guyenne, an ancient province of which Bordeaux was the capital. What is more likely is that the symbolic animal was inherited from the Kings of England: after Henry Plantagenet, Duke of Normandy and Count of Anjou, was crowned King Henry II of England, Aquitaine spent three centuries under English reign from 1154 until 1453.

content.title: Rue Gourmande, or the ‘Gastrothentic' empire

introduction.small: It is impossible to skip lunch or dinner if you find yourself on 'Gourmand Street', a Bordeaux landmark. You might even end up spending the night there.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Rue Gourmande, or the ‘Gastrothentic' empire

paragraphs.text:
In the heart of historical Bordeaux, between the Saint-Michel and Sainte Croix quarters, a talented entrepreneur and gourmet enthusiast has developed several food-based businesses, re-modelling an artery into a temple of regional specialities. Little by little, and thanks to the hard work of Jean-Pierre Xiradakis, the Rue Porte de la Monnaie built its reputation as "gourmet street". As you wander around, you will come across a country-style inn that sheds a light on gastronomic heritage (La Tupina). Close by, its sister restaurant and last-born on the street is La Petite Monnaie, which offers market-based cuisine that varies depending on seasons. Carry on and you will find a cellar and wine bar (Bar-Cave de la Monnaie) at the foot of the Porte de la Monnaie - the perfect opportunity to sample the wonders of the region (in moderation of course). You can even stop at a bed and breakfast (Maison Fredon).
Everything you need is on this 'concept-street' for indulging in the best of the seven deadly sins.

content.title: Le Pressoir d'Argent, Bordeaux gastronomy with a British signature

introduction.small: The presence of the Michelin-starred internationally renowned Brit Gordon Ramsay as chef of this gourmet restaurant at the InterContinental - Le Grand Hotel continues to be an event in itself.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Pressoir d'Argent, Bordeaux gastronomy with a British signature

paragraphs.text:
Seize this unique opportunity to discover Aquitaine haute cuisine at the most prestigious restaurant in town: the InterContinental Bordeaux. There, the contemporary sea-inspired decor of the Le Pressoir dining room and the sublime food are sure to leave you with an unforgettable memory.

Flavours form alliances in amazing dishes, including crab from Basque coast, avocado, citrus fruits, coriander and radish or locally-fished turbot in butter with crustacean marinière, seaweed and fregola, as well as specialties such as stir-fried duck foie gras, smoked duck breast with rhubarb and onions, whole pigeon, crispy giblets with beetroot and gingerbread and, of course, the famous “pressed European lobster” is sure to make an impression. The preparation of this last dish amounts to a kind of spectacle, as the celebrated solid-silver lobster press, which, having given its name to the restaurant, stands in the middle of the room, and plays its role to perfection, to the delight of the guests.

Le Pressoir d'Argent Gordon Ramsay

https://bordeaux.intercontinental.com/en/le-pressoir-dargent-gordon-ramsay/

content.title: Le Quatrième Mur, the curtain rises on spectacular cuisine

introduction.small: At Le Quatrième Mur - a reference to the imaginary “fourth wall” separating actors on stage from their audience - chef Philippe Etchebest brings diners quality bistro-inspired food.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Quatrième Mur, the curtain rises on spectacular cuisine

paragraphs.text:
Basque chef Philippe Etchebest opened the doors of his brasserie in the National Opera in September of 2015, creating an event in the historic heart of Bordeaux. In the sumptuous setting of a Bordeaux heritage landmark, this chic and contemporary restaurant, with affordable prices, represents the full extent of the French art of living, showcasing beauty and excellence side by side. The chef, who won two stars during his time at the Hostellerie de Plaisance in Saint-Émilion, is highly popular thanks to an exceptional TV career, having appeared in a number of cooking programmes. Faithful to the values ​​of sharing and generosity, he offers his fans, who come in great numbers to taste his creations, uninhibited cooking where taste is everything. The mushroom ravioli, stir-fried duck foie gras filet, creamy mushroom soup and sautéed quail filets, black Bigorre veil with spelt risotto and poultry dressing illustrate his strong affinity to the land, taking regional seasonal products to new heights. Now it is your turn to choose between the fancy brasserie or the starred table d'hôte.

Le Quatrième Mur

https://quatrieme-mur.com

content.title: Le Petit Bois and l'Autre Petit Bois, welcoming and unusual

introduction.small: Enjoy lunch or dinner under an artificial tree, see the world in a whole new light, and set it to rights over a delicious meal.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Le Petit Bois and l'Autre Petit Bois, welcoming and unusual

paragraphs.text:
On a downtown street or in Parliament Square, these two restaurants - no more than around 400m apart - are a popular meeting place for foodies and friends alike

As you step inside, delightfully quaint décor surrounds you: a cross between Hansel and Gretel's forest home and a thatched cottage of centuries past. The ornaments are equally quirky, with a hoard of flea market and garage sale trinkets piled high alongside a myriad of mismatches..

The atmosphere is cosy and intimate: chic alcoves reminiscent of magical forest groves are nestled amidst the imitation trees, giving it a deliberately romantic feel, and Louis XVI armchairs and tables are dotted throughout. There is a wonderful wine list featuring vintages from around the world to sample, along with charcuterie and cheese boards, casseroles, salads, hot sandwiches and pastries, all at very reasonable prices..

content.title: Mama Shelter: an urban concept in modern design, with an upbeat spirit

introduction.small: Mama Shelter's cofounder said it all: "Imagine a place that is neither luxurious nor a chain nor a low-cost, but something completely different altogether: it's Mama."

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Mama Shelter: an urban concept in modern design, with an upbeat spirit

paragraphs.text:
The Bordeaux edition of this trendy hotel, co-signed by the famous French designer Philippe Starck, opened in 2013. Dynamic and colourful, it is installed in the heart of the city, offering an ideally located home-away-from-home with modern, comfortable rooms (15 to 36 sqm) at affordable prices, an affordable restaurant serving simple but tasty home-made food, and a roof terrace for enjoying a drink outdoors. These are among the many assets that will make you a fan of Mama Shelter Bordeaux.

The quality of service and the welcome offered by the friendly staff also add to its appeal. Get ready for unforgettable weekend evenings when dance rhythms and DJ sets take over. After, in a comfortable bed adorned with fluffy pillows, you will sleep entwined in the arms of Morpheus and Mama.

content.title: Saint-Émilion, Medieval village and Grands Crus

introduction.small: Certain cities are noble-born: Saint-Émilion is one of them. The mere mention of it is enough to make your mouth water….

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Saint-Émilion, Medieval village and Grands Crus

paragraphs.text:
In 1999, for the first time ever, a vineyard landscape was propelled to the rank of a UNESCO World Heritage site. As attractive as its great wines are, Saint-Émilion itself is as beautiful as its reputation suggests. The harmonious work of man and nature is reflected in its landscapes, unique testimonies of history. Only 40 kilometres from Bordeaux, the city is carved like a jewel set amidst the vineyards; its streets of heavy paving stones plunge passers-by into a reverie of yore. Majestic spires soar upward, golden blond facades at dusk draw the eye, well-arranged shops and animated terraces extend their welcomes to passing tourists. The Tour du Roy and its dungeon are charged with mystery, and the cloister of the Collegiate Church resonates with the past. The panoramic view from the bell tower of the monolithic church is unparalleled, offering an overview of this bucolic landscape and the intimate details of the town itself. Take a stroll along the two-kilometre length of the walls from the Porte Brunet and explore the vineyards with friends, as a couple, with family, on foot or by bike.

content.title: Sainte-Catherine, the longest pedestrian street in Europe

introduction.small: In the midst of downtown, Sainte-Catherine Street was pedestrianised in 1977 and is now the longest shopping street in Europe, stretching over more than a kilometre.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Sainte-Catherine, the longest pedestrian street in Europe

paragraphs.text:
It is almost impossible to speak of Bordeaux, or to walk around it, without mentioning this street, highly popular with the Bordelais who came to do their shopping with their families on the weekends or with friends during the week. You will find it easily, as it stretches all the way from the Cours de l'Intendance - a staple of the Golden Triangle - straight to the most popular student area of the Place de la Victoire. With more than 230 stores, St. Catherine is often inundated by crowds of people. Outside of the holiday season, visitors tend to be at their most numerous during the bi-annual street markets in February and July. Both local and itinerant merchants set up their stalls to attract the curious in search of bargains with each new iteration.

The "Promenade Sainte-Catherine" - a new complex with a modern, village-style appearance - was opened in October 2015, and harmoniously integrated into the heart of Old Bordeaux. Despite the hubbub of the city streets outside, the atmosphere indoors is calm and serene. The space contains more than a hundred homes, as well as an 18,000 sqm shopping centre with about 30 stores.

content.title: La Co(o)rniche, for lovers of the Arcachon Bay

introduction.small: Right at the heart of Arcachon Bay, the 5-star La Co(o)rniche offers incomparable views over the Dune du Pilat, Cap Ferret and the Banc d'Anguin.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: La Co(o)rniche, for lovers of the Arcachon Bay

paragraphs.text:
Philippe Starck, the renowned French designer behind the décor at La Co(o)rniche, sums the place up in a single sentence: “This is not just the most beautiful place in the bay, it is the most beautiful place in the world”. The amazement you experience upon entering the hotel is nothing to that you will feel when you finally look out on its incredible surroundings. Just a few metres from the Dune du Pilat, La Co(o)rniche enjoys exceptional views of this surreal towering mountain of sand, which has been named a “Grand Site de France”.

The hotel, restaurant, terrace, and bar comprise an ensemble that has become an institution since opening in 2010. It is a must, an admirable edifice that celebrates the wonderful authenticity of its preserved Basque architecture. The main house offers rooms and suites complete with balconies and terraces that give onto the Arcachon Bay. The establishment also provides more intimate cabins, inspired by oyster-farming villages, each of which enjoys a fabulous view down to the Banc d'Arguin national nature reserve. It is hard not to fall into hyperbole at the thought of this unparalleled Eden.

La Co(o)rniche
46 avenue Louis Gaume
33115 Pyla-sur-Mer

www.lacoorniche-pyla.com/en/

Rooms: from 275 EUR

content.title: Hotel Le Burdigala, modern sophistication at the gates of Old Bordeaux

introduction.small: Located just steps from the historic centre - away from the urban bustle, Le Burdigala owes its name to that of the old Gallo-Roman city which became Bordeaux.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Hotel Le Burdigala, modern sophistication at the gates of Old Bordeaux

paragraphs.text:
This 4-star hotel, a member of the Inwood Hotels group, has been fully renovated and has embraced the challenge of creating contemporary, sober, and yet warm décor. The 'spirit' of Bordeaux so dear to the great French thinkers and writers like Montaigne, Montesquieu and, Mauriac is unveiled behind its white stone porch.

This renowned establishment offers a refined and discreet setting with exemplary respect for service and a welcoming atmosphere. Its 83 bedrooms - superior, duplex or suites - are serene havens that offer comfortable living space for all, including families with children. In this cosy ambience, gourmet cuisine is featured at 'La Table du Burdigala' with drinks at the Bacchus Bar. As one might expect of the world wine capital, wine enthusiasts will find the greatest classic crus of Bordeaux here, albeit to be enjoyed in moderation.

content.title: Cap Sciences: the awakening of consciousness

introduction.small: Have fun discovering and understanding scientific phenomena.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: Cap Sciences: the awakening of consciousness

paragraphs.text:
This semi-public and semi-private structure operates on the same educational principle as the Cité des Sciences et de l'Industrie in Paris. It belongs to the network of centres for scientific, technical, and industrial culture, with both permanent and touring exhibitions and events designed to appeal to a wide audience.

Open to the eyes of all, Cap Sciences is an imposing building, located on the docks of Bordeaux, where presentations on scientific and technical subjects are offered. Children, their parents, and teachers, know that it is also a place where one can learn how to conduct a scientific investigation, build a rocket, or make objects with a 3D printer. However, what many people do not know is that Cap Sciences is also spread over three other locations in the Bordeaux suburbs (Pessac, Floirac and Mérignac), that it controls the Aquitaine network promoting scientific culture, that it is at the forefront of virtual communities without borders, or that it advises other cultural structures.

Cap Sciences is a galaxy whose expansion velocity is proportional to the number of people who run it, so come for a visit on your own or with family, and open your own field of possibilities.

Cap Sciences
Hangar 20 - Quai de Bacalan
33300 Bordeaux

+33 (0)5 56 01 07 07

https://www.cap-sciences.net

content.title: L'Estacade, a culinary getaway on the water across from Bordeaux

introduction.small: Savour refined world cuisine in an exceptional setting while comfortably seated on the terrace overlooking the left bank of Bordeaux.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: L'Estacade, a culinary getaway on the water across from Bordeaux

paragraphs.text:
All your senses will be awakened in this vast fishing hut set on stilts above the Garonne, with panoramic views of the Water Mirror and the Place de la Bourse reflected in it, shining brightly at nightfall. On moonlit evenings it is a sight to behold as it appears to float dreamlike through the air. Materials play an important role in this natural setting with zinc teasing wood and glass to reflect a stylish Zen atmosphere.

As for the restaurant menu, it fuses various Mediterranean and Atlantic flavours: cuttlefish filets in parsley and garlic or lime-marinated foie gras for starters, lobster risotto and Thai basil, or duck breast en croûte with glazed carrots in cumin for main. This culinary alchemy transforms produce of land and sea into deliciously-fragranced dishes: perfect for pairing with a selection of reasonably priced Southern wines.

L'Estacade
Quai des Queyries
33100 Bordeaux

+33 (0)5 57 54 02 50

https://www.estacade-restaurant.com/en/

Menu: around 47 EUR

content.title: InterContinental Bordeaux – Le Grand Hotel, excellence in service

introduction.small: Facing the Grand Theatre, this masterful gem of the Bordeaux hotel trade has been entirely renovated by famous designer Jacques Garcia.

mainPicture.accessibilityDescription: InterContinental Bordeaux – Le Grand Hotel, excellence in service

paragraphs.text:
The five-star hotel strives to offer the short-stay guest or the well-to-do resident unforgettable memories of an almost-improbable moment of rare exception, in an enchanting and luxurious setting. Firmly ensconced in the heart of the Girondine capital, the building - designed by architect Victor Louis in the late 18th century - has been home to both Jean de Sacriste and the Comte de Roly, and provided a source of admiration and curiosity for over 200 years.

The 130 rooms and suites of the InterContinental Bordeaux - Le Grand Hôtel combine tradition and glamour in décor that is almost theatrical in nature, comprised of plush curtains and classic furniture in fine upholstery. The heated marble floors of the bathrooms, meanwhile, add a generous dash of comfort.

Give yourself an afternoon relaxing in the spa, which is spread over three levels, before dining at the Michelin-starred Pressoir d'Argent restaurant, brought to you by top celebrity chef Gordon Ramsay. On the top floor, the royal suite with open-air Jacuzzi offers a captivating view of Bordeaux, as does the rooftop terrace of the Night Beach lounge bar, which becomes one of the most popular hotspots in Bordeaux every summer: a jungle of lush greenery right in the heart of the city.

InterContinental Bordeaux - Le Grand Hôtel
2-5 place de la Comédie
33000 Bordeaux

+33 (0)5 57 30 44 44

https://bordeaux.intercontinental.com/en/

Rooms: from 213 EUR

content.title: CLIMATE AND WEATHER IN Bordeaux
content.introduction: Because the Bordeaux region is situated on the Atlantic coast, the city and its surrounding area have a maritime climate, with mild winters (from December to March) and very warm summers. Temperatures can often exceed 35°C (95°F) in the summer months. It rains fairly frequently throughout the year, with thunderstorms in the summer. Nevertheless, the city is still quite sunny, with more than 2,000 hours of sunshine per year, making Bordeaux a top tourist destination.

airports.title: Bordeaux Mérignac Airport
airports.description:
Bordeaux Airport is located in the town of Mérignac, about
12 kilometres (7.5 miles) west of Bordeaux.
  • One terminal

Getting from the airport to Bordeaux and back:
  • By car
    • Accessible via exit 11b of the Bordeaux ring road.
    • Five parking facilities available at the airport:
      • Express (drop-off area): a one-minute walk from the terminal, free for the first 10 minutes.
      • P0 Comfort: a one-minute walk from the terminal. Prices start at EUR 27 for 12 hours.
      • P1 Proxi: a few minutes' walk from the terminal. Prices start at EUR 23 for 12 hours.
      • P2 Flexi: a few minutes' walk from the terminal. Prices start at EUR 21 for 12 hours.
      • P4 Long-Stay: 10 minutes from the terminal, free
        shuttle service provided. Prices start at EUR 12 for 12 hours.
    • Several car rental companies have counters at the airport, on
      Level 0 in the connecting wing between halls A and B.
  • By shuttle bus (30'Direct)
    • A shuttle bus service connects the airport to Bordeaux's Saint-Jean train station in 30 minutes and operates 7/7. Buses leave every hour from the airport (outside hall B, exit 7) between 7.25 a.m. and 8 p.m. during the week, and between 8:45 a.m. and 6 p.m. on Saturdays and Sundays. Buses run from the Saint-Jean train station between 6:30 a.m. and 7:15 p.m. during the week, and between 8:10 a.m. and 5:15 p.m. at weekends. A single ticket costs EUR 8 and a return is EUR 16. For more information, go to https://30direct.com/en/
  • By bus (Lianes 1)
    • This bus line offers a direct link between Saint-Jean train station and the airport via central Bordeaux and Mérignac. It runs from 4:45 a.m. until 12:20 a.m. (or 1:20 a.m. on Thursdays, Fridays and Saturdays), with a bus usually departing every 8-10 minutes. Single tickets cost EUR 1.70. For more information, go to https://www.infotbm.com/fr/lignes/01/
  • By taxi
    • Taxis are available just outside the airport. The fare to Bordeaux
      is about EUR 30 (night fare is about EUR 45).
  • Services: shops, bars and restaurants, valet parking,
    free Internet access (Wi-Fi), etc.
  • Telephone: +33 (0)5 56 34 50 50
  • Website: https://www.bordeaux.aeroport.fr/en
  • Train + Air Service
    Customers connecting to Paris (Orly or Charles de Gaulle) who have an Air France flight number must visit the Train + Air desk at the Bordeaux Saint-Jean station between 24 hours and 20 minutes before departure: train tickets will be issued to them upon presentation of a valid airplane ticket.
  • You will find all necessary information on the website:
    https://www.airfrance.fr/FR/en/common/resainfovol/avion_train/reservation_avion_train_tgvair_airfrance.htm
  • The Bordeaux Saint-Jean TGV station is located at 1 rue Charles
    Domercq, 33800 Bordeaux. It is open every day from 4:00 a.m. to 1:00
    a.m. (4:00 a.m. to 2:00 a.m. on Friday):
    • Access via public transportation: tramway (line C), intercity buses
      (TransGironde), mainline coaches, city buses (Lianes 9, Lianes 1,
      Lianes 10, Lianes 11).
    • Access via private transportation: drop off area,
      self-service car sharing, rental car companies, taxis, parking lots,
      bike rentals.

For all necessary information about the Train + Air desk, please visit
https://www.garesetconnexions.sncf/fr/gare/frboj/bordeaux-saint-jean/services/espace-vente

localCalendar.title: FESTIVALS, HOLIDAYS AND OTHER ANNUAL EVENTS IN Bordeaux
localCalendar.description: There are a number of festivals, holidays and other events celebrated in Bordeaux each year. The main ones are listed below.

events.title: March or April: Easter Monday (national holiday)
May 1: Labour Day (national holiday)
events.description: On the first of May, it is customary to offer a sprig of lily-of-the-valley to close ones. Many vendors occupy the pavement on that occasion!

events.title: May 8: Victory Day (national holiday)
events.description: Commemorates the Allied victory in Europe that ended World War II on this day in 1945. Various ceremonies are held around town.

events.title: June 21: Fête de la Musique (celebrated nationwide)
events.description: Also celebrated internationally as World Music Day, for this festival many free concerts featuring all types of music are held in the streets and at various venues across Bordeaux.

events.title: June: Bordeaux Fête le Vin (local event)
events.description: A wine trail stretching for over a mile in central Bordeaux, this incredible event is an opportunity for various animations, concerts and other shows along the banks of the Garonne River!

events.title: Summer season: Scènes d'Été (local event along the Gironde estuary)
events.description: With music, dance, theatre and street arts, this programme of over 500 events (more than half of which are free), jointly organized by over 200 of the region's towns and cities, is perfect for outings with family members or friends.

events.title: July 14 : Bastille Day (national holiday)
events.description: This holiday celebrates both the storming of the Bastille prison in 1789, the key event marking the beginning of the French Revolution. It plays as a symbol of the end of the privileges enjoyed by the clergy and the aristocracy. In Bordeaux, this anniversary is commemorated each year with a fireworks display over the Garonne River between the Pont de Pierre and the Place de la Bourse. Wonderful!

events.title: August 15: Assumption Day  (national)
events.description: This celebration, still very popular in Bordeaux, is marked by the faithful with religious ceremonies. Expect fireworks over the Garonne River. The best spot to enjoy them is assuredly on the riverbanks.

events.title: 3rd in September: European Heritage Days (national)
events.description: The aim of the European Heritage Days is to open up numerous sites and monuments, many of which are normally closed to the public, such as castles and private collections. A great opportunity for a lovely stroll through the city to admire architectural treasures!

events.title: November 11: Remembrance Day (national holiday)
events.description: On this day, French citizens gather at war memorials to commemorate the signing of the 1918 Armistice officially bringing an end to the First World War.

events.title: December 31: New Year's Eve (national event)
events.description: On the night of December 31<sup>st</sup>, the atmosphere is particularly festive on the streets of Bordeaux, with families and friends celebrating the new year.

Tipping
In Bordeaux like elsewhere in France, a service charge is always included in the bill. If you are particularly pleased with the service, you may certainly leave a few extra euros on the table. But this additional tip is neither expected nor necessary.
